review.title: Robust Budget Allocation via Continuous Submodular Functions
review.abstract: The optimal allocation of resources for maximizing influence, spread of information or coverage, has gained attention in the past years, in particular in machine learning and data mining. But, in applications, the parameters of the problem are rarely known exactly, and using wrong parameters can lead to undesirable outcomes. We hence revisit a continuous version of the Budget Allocation or Bipartite Influence Maximization problem introduced by Alon et al. (2012) from a robust optimization perspective, where an adversary may choose the least favorable parameters within a confidence set. The resulting problem is a nonconvex-concave saddle point problem (or game). We show that this nonconvex problem can be solved exactly by leveraging connections to continuous submodular functions, and by solving a constrained submodular minimization problem. Although constrained submodular minimization is hard in general, here, we establish conditions under which such a problem can be solved to arbitrary precision $\epsilon$.

sections.heading: 4.2 Yahoo! data
sections.text: To evaluate our method on the basis of real-world data, we formulate a budget allocation instance on the bid data of the advertiser Yahoo! Webscope [yah]. This record logs bids on 1000 different phrases through advertising accounts. We assign the phrases to channels S and customer accounts T, with a head start between s and t when a corresponding bid has been submitted. For each pair (s, t), we consistently subtract the associated transmission probability from [0, 0.4]. We tend these to zero because we expect that people will not be so easily influenced by advertising in the real world. Then, we generate an estimate and build up a latecomer by generating nst samples from Ber (pst), where nst is the number of bids between s and t in the data set. This transformation results in a two-part graph with | S | = 1000, T | = 10475 and more than the typical gap between the 50,000 people in the budget.

sections.heading: 4.3 Comparison to first-order methods
sections.text: Given the success of first-order methods for non-convex problems in practice, it is natural to compare them with our method for determining the worst-case vector x. In one of our Yahoo problem cases with fixed D-standard uncertainty, we compared our sub-modular minimization scheme with Frank-Wolfe's fixed step size as in [Lacoste-Julien, 2016], implementing the linear oracle with MOSEK [MOSEK ApS, 2015]. Interestingly, Frank-Wolfe finds an optimal solution from various initializations, as confirmed by comparison with the guaranteed solution of our algorithm. Note that due to non-convexity, there are no formal guarantees that Frank-Wolfe is optimal here, which motivates the question of the global convergence properties of Frank-Wolfe in the presence of submodularity.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We deal with the problem of uncertain parameters (or faulty model specification) in Budget Allocation or Bipartite Influence Maximization [Alon et al., 2012] from a robust optimization perspective. The resulting Robust Budget Allocation is a non-convex concave saddle point problem. Although the inner optimization problem is non-convex, we show how continuous submodularity can be used to solve the problem with arbitrary accuracy problems, as verified by the suggested limits of the duality gap. In particular, our approach extends continuous submodular minimization methods [Bach, 2015] to more general limitations and introduces a mechanism for solving a new class of necessarily non-convex optimization problems. We confirm, based on synthetic and real data, that our method finds high-quality solutions that are robust to parameters that vary at will in a certain degree of uncertainty, up to and beyond 50,000 scale.
